title: FINDRISC (Finnish Diabetes Risk Score)
description: Identifies patients at high risk for type 2 diabetes within 10 years without the need for laboratory tests

parameters.name: gender
parameters.description: Patient gender (needed for waist circumference evaluation)

parameters.name: physical_activity
parameters.description: Physical activity at least 30 minutes per day or ≥4 hours per week

parameters.name: fruit_vegetable_consumption
parameters.description: Daily consumption of fruits, vegetables, or berries

parameters.name: high_blood_glucose_history
parameters.description: History of high blood glucose (e.g., during health examination, illness, or pregnancy)

result.name: risk_score
result.description: Total FINDRISC score indicating 10-year risk of developing type 2 diabetes

ranges.interpretation: Estimated 1 in 100 will develop diabetes within 10 years. 10-year risk: Men 0.3%, Women 0.1%
Estimated 1 in 25 will develop diabetes within 10 years. 10-year risk: Men 0.8%, Women 0.4%
Estimated 1 in 6 will develop diabetes within 10 years. 10-year risk: Men 2.6%, Women 2.2%
Estimated 1 in 3 will develop diabetes within 10 years. 10-year risk: Men 23.1%, Women 14.1%. Consider lifestyle changes and possibly medication
Estimated 1 in 2 will develop diabetes within 10 years. 10-year risk: 50%. Lifestyle changes needed; consider medications to prevent diabetes

references: Lindström J, Tuomilehto J. The diabetes risk score: a practical tool to predict type 2 diabetes risk. Diabetes Care. 2003 Mar;26(3):725-31. doi: 10.2337/diacare.26.3.725.

Saaristo T, Peltonen M, Lindström J, Saarikoski L, Sundvall J, Eriksson JG, et al. Cross-sectional evaluation of the Finnish Diabetes Risk Score: a tool to identify undetected type 2 diabetes, abnormal glucose tolerance and metabolic syndrome. Diab Vasc Dis Res. 2005 May;2(2):67-72. doi: 10.3132/dvdr.2005.011.

Tankova T, Chakarova N, Atanassova I, Dakovska L. Evaluation of the Finnish Diabetes Risk Score as a screening tool for impaired fasting glucose, impaired glucose tolerance and undetected diabetes. Diabetes Res Clin Pract. 2011 Apr;92(1):46-52. doi: 10.1016/j.diabres.2010.12.020.
formula: Sum of points based on: Age (0-4 points) + BMI (0-3 points) + Waist circumference (0-4 points) + Physical activity (0-2 points) + Fruit/vegetable consumption (0-1 point) + Blood pressure medication (0-2 points) + High blood glucose history (0-5 points) + Family diabetes history (0-5 points)
notes: First degree relatives include parents, siblings, or children
Second degree relatives include grandparents, aunts, uncles, or cousins
Waist circumference thresholds differ by gender: Men (normal <94cm, elevated 94-102cm, high ≥102cm); Women (normal <80cm, elevated 80-88cm, high ≥88cm)
No laboratory tests required for this assessment
